assign.name: Plan a “Which One Doesn’t Belong?” Activity
assign.intro:
In Session 5.3, you experienced the routine “Which One Doesn’t Belong?” This routine could be used as the introduction to a lesson, as a review of previously learned material, or as a formative assessment opportunity for the teacher. The time allotted is typically 10–15 minutes.

The general guidelines for this routine are:

  • Learners look at a set of four mathematical objects (geometric figures, expressions, equations, etc.), and choose one object that does not belong with the others.
    • There could be a reason why each object doesn’t belong with the others. This is not a “multiple choice” question, although students may expect it to be.
  • Learners have independent think time (1–2 minutes) to make their choice and prepare to share their choice and reasoning with a small group.
  • In small groups, learners share and discuss their choices, and if time permits and they have not already done so, generate a reason why each object “doesn’t belong” with the others.
  • As a whole group, the teacher facilitates a discussion, soliciting choices and reasons.
    • The teacher asks questions like: “Can you clarify what you mean by . . . ?” or “Did anyone make that choice, but for a different reason?” or “Does anyone disagree?”
    • The purpose of the discussion is for the learners to practice speaking and listening, as well as for the teacher to learn the terminology adult learners use and what knowledge and understanding they bring.

Assignment

  1. Draft a “Which One Doesn’t Belong?” activity for your adult learners. You may use figures from an activity in this module, create your own, or find inspiration at the website wodb.ca/shapes.html. Sets of shapes of particular relevance to this module are #1, 2, 3, 27, 32, 33, 45, 47, 53, 55, 56, 57, 67, or 70.
  2. Respond to the following questions:
    • What topic in geometry does your activity relate to?
    • What are some reasons your adult learners might give for why each object doesn’t belong with the others?
    • What do you think you will learn about what adult learners struggle with? What aspects of precision will you learn about?
  3. Optional: Implement the activity with a group of adult learners and share what you learned.

Instructions for submitting the assignment: Click the ADD SUBMISSION button below. You may then type your responses in the text box or upload files. Click SAVE CHANGES to save your work. Click SUBMIT ASSIGNMENT when you are done.
